Award.AwardTitle: Surface, Boundary Layer and Cloud Interactions of Energy, Water and Carbon Dioxide (CO2)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Considerable progress has been made in evaluating the present generation of global models and reanalyses, but there are still deficiencies in their physical parameterizations, particularly in the modeling of energy and water transports at the land surface, and in the coupling of the surface and boundary layer to clouds and precipitation. This research advances the understanding of the interactions between the land surface fluxes of energy, water and carbon dioxide with clouds and precipitation, in support of global analysis and modeling of the earth's land-atmosphere system.

Intellectual merit: The PI will (1) analyze flux tower datasets, examine their use for evaluating the representation of physical processes in global models, and evaluate global reanalyses on river basin scales, and (2) develop idealized models for the atmospheric boundary layer.

Broader Impacts: The research will improve medium-range and seasonal weather forecasting, and quantify the component of the surface CO2 budget associated with natural vegetation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary research focus has been on understanding and modeling how clouds and climate processes are linked to land-surface processes. I have evaluated data and models for specific regions, like the boreal forest in Canada and the Amazon forest, as well as locally in New England. I have also helped evaluate and improve the global analyses for the weather and climate over land. Some research has explained familiar but poorly understood processes. For example, how the radiative cooling to space, which depends on the greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, controls the daily range of temperature between the afternoon maximum and the minimum at sunrise; and how this changes in the spring as the northern forests leaf out. Another simplified model explains how surface evaporation, cloud cover and land-surface temperature are likely to change if CO2 in the atmosphere doubles later this century.

 

My research is directly related to the climate change that is being driven by the increase of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. So I am frequently asked to explain what is happening to the climate of New England and Vermont, the state where I live, to schools, businesses, environmental groups and state government. So my recent papers address how global changes are locally affecting Vermont. I have developed climate change indicators for Vermont, which describe, in terms familiar to the public, how the seasons are changing and the winter frozen period is shrinking. I have worked with the State Agency of Natural Resources to plan how the state might adapt to ongoing climate change.

 

Humanity will be unable to deal with climate change, both in terms of mitigation and adaptation, until a broad spectrum of society is fluent in discussing the issues and the choices we face. This means Earth scientists have a responsibility for clear, open public communication. So I also write articles for the Sunday environment section of two Vermont newspapers (which I helped establish in 2008). These illustrate weather, climate and policy issues as they arise during the year. Finally I have set up a public archive (http://alanbetts.com/ ) for all my research, public talks and writings, including a page which addresses “Understanding Climate Change”.
